definition: to begin/to open/to start/beginning of an event

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format
threshing floor/classifier for events and happenings: spell, episode, bout
large place used for a specific purpose/stage/scene (of a play)/classifier for sporting or recreational activities/classifier for number of exams
variant of 場|场[chang2]
variant of 場|场[chang3]
prologue of play/opening remarks/preamble (of speeches, articles etc)

sentences.english: The team failed to capitalize on their early lead.
sentences.chinese: 这个队未能充分利用开场时领前的优势。

sentences.english: On this high note the puppet show commences .
sentences.chinese: 木偶戏就在这阵高昂的调子里开场了。

sentences.english: The movie begins with Superman’s failed search for Krypton.
sentences.chinese: 电影以超人寻找氪星人失败开场。

sentences.english: By way of an introduction, I'd just like to give some historical background for this issue.
sentences.chinese: 作为开场白，我来解释一下这件事的历史背景。

sentences.english: Let's just hope that we're just seeing a few getting-started hiccups.
sentences.chinese: 我们都希望看到的仅仅是几个开场曲。

sentences.english: You don't engage in prolonged public displays of affection.
sentences.chinese: 你不会在公开场合长时间直露自己的情绪。

sentences.english: She begins by opening a colorful hatbox.
sentences.chinese: 她常用一个色彩斑斓的冒盒作为自己的开场。

sentences.english: Added new movie to boot Imperial Company (Julii) and the introductory video.
sentences.chinese: 增加了新的尤利乌斯家族帝国会战开场介绍性动画。

sentences.english: In other words, this kind of question is often a lead-in to a suggestion or invitation.
sentences.chinese: 换言之，这种问题通常是建议或邀请的开场白。

sentences.english: The play opens on a cold night at Elsinore, the Danish royal castle.
sentences.chinese: 该剧开场于艾尔西诺皇家城堡一个寒冷的夜晚。

sentences.english: River had gone 1-0 up within the first five minutes.
sentences.chinese: 河床在开场五分钟就取得领先。

sentences.english: I'm talking about intros that ooze with concern.
sentences.chinese: 我讲的是富有关怀的开场白。

sentences.english: But he ain’t had time to get good started yet.
sentences.chinese: 可是眼下，他恐怕还没来得及准备好开场白呢。

sentences.english: Host and win 10 matches with at least 6 players present.
sentences.chinese: 开场且赢这10场配对，但至少需6位玩家同场。

sentences.english: The Sunday afternoon class' version of "The Little Prince" got off to the strongest start of all three shows.
sentences.chinese: 周日下午班的“小王子”的开场戏是三场中最出色的。

definition: to go on stage/fig. to appear on the scene/used in advertising to mean new product
opening (chess etc)/early stage of game, match, work, activity etc
everyone present/the whole audience/across-the-board/unanimously/whole duration (of a competition or match)
debut
second half (of sporting competition)
half of a game or contest/half-court
(of a performer) to come onto the stage to perform/(of an athlete) to enter the arena to compete/(fig.) to enter the scene (e.g. a new product)/(of an examinee etc) to leave the venue
competition (sports etc)/match/CL:場|场[chang3],次[ci4]/to compete
end (of a performance or sports match)/last round of testing in the imperial examinations
on stage/to go on stage/to take the field
score
to go smoothly/to come off/to succeed
lit. the guest acts as host (idiom); fig. to turn from passive to active behavior
to equalize/to level the score/to pull back the advantage
high tide/high water/upsurge/climax/orgasm/chorus (part of a song)
termination/to finish/to end/to conclude/to close
